question_details.query: What is the evidence for actions that can mitigate environmental pollution from salmon farming?
What husbandry practices, beyond feed and chemical treatments, can be used on Atlantic salmon farms to improve fish health?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several non-feed, non-chemical husbandry measures for Atlantic salmon. Implementing fallowing has been associated with lower sea lice numbers on salmon in Scotland, though one study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease [1026]. Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents showed mixed outcomes: one controlled study found corkwing and goldsinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments at controlling lice, while another found rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks [738]. Adjusting lighting intensity can influence lice levels, with lower-intensity artificial light or natural lighting associated with fewer lice, and higher-intensity artificial light associated with more lice [741]. Selective breeding for disease resistance improved survival when fish were exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with families bred for high resistance showing higher survival than low-resistance families [735]. Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms reduced salmon losses to harbour seal predation [2774]. Additionally, fallowing cycles were associated with recovery of benthic communities beneath cages toward non-impacted conditions, which relates to farm environmental management [1027].
summary_statements: Several non-feed, non-chemical husbandry measures exist for Atlantic salmon.
Implementing fallowing has been associated with lower sea lice numbers on salmon in Scotland.
One study in Australia found that fallowing resulted in no difference in salmon mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease.
Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents for sea lice has shown mixed outcomes.

question_details.query: Among non-pesticide interventions, which appear most consistently effective for controlling parasites like sea lice on farmed salmon?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Cleaner wrasse show mixed effectiveness—one controlled study in Ireland found corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse controlled lice as effectively as chemical treatments, while a replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks [738]. Altering lighting reduced lice: a replicated, controlled study in Norway reported lower lice numbers under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting, with higher lice counts under more intense artificial light [741]. Fallowing had variable outcomes: a study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system, while another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing had been used [1026]. Probiotic/immunostimulant feeding reduced lice: a replicated, controlled study in Norway found lice infection was reduced by 28% with a diet including 28% plant-based protein, and adding beta-glucans decreased lice levels by a further 28% compared with controls; the same action also reports improved gut function with mannan oligosaccharides and increased survival after bacterial challenge in a separate Scottish study [732].
summary_statements: Cleaner wrasse show mixed effectiveness in controlling sea lice on farmed salmon.
A controlled study in Ireland found that corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse controlled lice as effectively as chemical treatments.
A replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks.
Altering lighting was found to reduce lice on farmed salmon.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway reported lower lice numbers on farmed salmon under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
The same Norwegian study found higher lice counts on farmed salmon under more intense artificial light.
Fallowing, as a method for parasite control, had variable outcomes.
A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages that used a fallowing system.
A study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing had been used.
Probiotic and immunostimulant feeding reduced lice on farmed salmon.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that a diet including 28% plant-based protein reduced lice infection by 28%.
In the same Norwegian study, adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
Feeding with mannan oligosaccharides was reported to improve gut function in farmed fish.
A separate Scottish study reported increased survival in farmed fish after a bacterial challenge.

question_details.query: Besides fallowing, what other methods can mitigate the impact of salmon farms on the surrounding benthic environment and local species?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified non-fallowing methods include: using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents for sea lice, with mixed results—two studies in Ireland reported that corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse controlled lice comparably to chemicals, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective [738]. Integrated aquaculture systems (e.g., co-culturing bivalves/algae near fish farms) showed that scallops grew more adjacent to farms (USA), blue mussels absorbed salmon-farm waste (Canada), and algae growth was enhanced near farms (Scotland), though one study found oysters and mussels were not feeding on fish-farm waste (Spain) [932]. Additional proposed approaches—improving fish food/pellets to reduce waste [2192], reducing aquaculture stocking densities [2186], reducing antibiotic use [2194], siting farms in areas with fast currents [2188], placing artificial reefs near farms to act as biofilters [2196], using other bioremediation methods [2197], and locating farms in vegetated areas [2189]—had no studies identified that evaluated effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.
summary_statements: Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents for sea lice is one non-fallowing method to mitigate the impact of salmon farms.
The use of cleaner wrasse as a control for sea lice has shown mixed results.
Two studies in Ireland reported that corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse controlled sea lice comparably to chemical treatments.
In two studies in Ireland, rockcook wrasse were found to be ineffective at controlling sea lice.
Integrated aquaculture systems, such as co-culturing bivalves and algae near fish farms, have been studied as a mitigation method.
A study in the USA showed that scallops grew more when located adjacent to fish farms.
A study in Canada found that blue mussels absorbed waste from salmon farms.
A study in Scotland showed that algae growth was enhanced near fish farms.
One study in Spain found that oysters and mussels were not feeding on waste from fish farms.
Improving fish food and pellets to reduce waste is a proposed approach to mitigate the impacts of salmon farms.
Reducing aquaculture stocking densities is a proposed approach to mitigate salmon farm impacts.
Reducing the use of antibiotics in aquaculture is a proposed mitigation approach.
Siting farms in areas with fast currents is a proposed approach to mitigate salmon farm impacts.
Placing artificial reefs near farms to act as biofilters is a proposed mitigation method.
Using other bioremediation methods is a proposed approach to mitigate salmon farm impacts.
Locating farms in vegetated areas is a proposed approach to mitigate salmon farm impacts.
No studies were identified that evaluated the effects of several proposed mitigation approaches on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

question_details.query: Beyond chemical treatments, what alternative methods are available to control sea lice on Atlantic salmon farms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several non-chemical approaches: Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents showed mixed results; in Ireland, corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments at controlling lice, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing outbreaks (ID 738). Adjusting lighting reduced lice burdens; a replicated, controlled study in Norway reported fewer lice under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting, with higher artificial light intensity associated with more lice (ID 741). Implementing fallowing systems was associated with lower lice numbers on salmon cages in a study from Scotland (ID 1026). Dietary strategies reduced lice infection levels; in Norway, feeding a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced the number of salmon infected with lice by 28%, and adding beta-glucans further decreased lice infection by 28% compared with controls (ID 732).
summary_statements: Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents for sea lice showed mixed results.
In Ireland, corkwing and goldsinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments at controlling lice.
Rockcook wrasse were ineffective at preventing sea lice outbreaks.
Adjusting lighting on Atlantic salmon farms reduced lice burdens.
A study in Norway reported fewer lice on salmon under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
Higher artificial light intensity was associated with more lice on salmon.
Implementing fallowing systems was associated with lower lice numbers on salmon cages.
Dietary strategies reduced lice infection levels in salmon.
In Norway, feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced the number of fish infected with lice by 28%.
Adding beta-glucans to a salmon's diet further decreased lice infection by 28% compared with controls.
